contentrichtext.text: '''Trinoda necessitas''' ("three-knotted obligation" <ref>{{Cite book | publisher = Oxford University Press | isbn = 0-198-64224-5 | last = Souter | first = Alexander | title = Oxford Latin Dictionary|date=1968}}</ref> in [[Latin]]) is a term used to refer to a "threefold tax" in [[Anglo-Saxon England|Anglo-Saxon]] times. Subjects of an Anglo-Saxon king were required to yield three services: bridge-bote (repairing [[bridge]]s and roads), burgh-bote (building and maintaining [[fortification]]s), and fyrd-bote (serving in the [[militia]], known as the [[fyrd]]). Rulers very rarely exempted subjects from the ''trinoda necessitas'', because these services were the lifeblood of an Anglo-Saxon kingdom.<ref>{{Cite book | publisher = Wiley-Blackwell | isbn = 0-631-22492-0 | last = Lapidge | first = Michael | coauthors = John Blair, Simon Keynes, Donald Scragg | title = The Blackwell Encyclopaedia of Anglo-Saxon England | pages = 456–457 | date = 2000-11-15 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book | edition = 3 | publisher = Oxford University Press, USA | isbn = 0-19-280139-2 | last = Stenton | first = Frank M. | title = Anglo-Saxon England: Reissue with a new cover | page = 289 | date = 2001-09-20 }}</ref> After the [[Norman Conquest]], exemptions from the ''trinoda necessitas'' became more common.<ref name=Hollister/> The term "trinoda necessitas" was rarely used in Anglo-Saxon times: its only known use is in a grant of land near [[Pagham]], [[Sussex]] from King [[Cædwalla of Wessex]] to [[Saint Wilfred]].<ref name=stevenson>{{cite journal|journal=The English Historical Review|title=Trinoda Necessitas|volume=29|issue=66|date=October 1914|first=W.H.|last=Stevenson}}</ref> The Wilfred grant used the term ''trimoda'' (Latin for "triple"); ''trinoda'' (Latin for "triple-knotted") was an error introduced by [[John Selden]] in 1610.<ref name=stevenson/><ref name=eb1911>{{cite encyclopedia|article=Trinoda Necessitas|encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Britannica|date=1911}}</ref> Instead of the term "trinoda necessitas", it was common for Anglo-Saxon land grants to spell out the three obligations individually. For example, the land grant of [[Ethelbert of Kent]] to a [[thegn]] in 858 was free of obligation, except explicitly for military service, bridge repair, and fortification.<ref name=Hollister>{{cite book|title=Anglo-Saxon Military Obligations on the Eve of the Norman Conquest|first=C. Warren|last=Hollister|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1962|page=60}}</ref> ==See also== *[[History of English land law]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Anglo-Saxon law]] [[Category:History of taxation in the United Kingdom]] {{England-hist-stub}}
